title: RL32782
content: In February 2002, the Bush Administration proposed "Clear Skies" to address emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, mercury, and carbon dioxide. The proposal aimed to amend the Clean Air Act with emission caps on electric utility emissions, implemented through a tradeable allowance program in two phases: 2010 and 2018. A modified version of Clear Skies was introduced in the 109th Congress as S. 131 by Senator Inhofe, sparking debates on its cap-and-trade implementation scheme. The Clear Skies proposal introduced by Senator Inhofe focuses on cap-and-trade provisions for emissions reductions of SO2, NOx, and mercury. EPA's approach aims to reduce costs and increase certainty for industry, regulators, and consumers. The proposal interacts with the Clean Air Act through regional cap-and-trade programs already in place for NOx emissions control. The Clear Skies proposal introduced by Senator Inhofe focuses on cap-and-trade provisions for emissions reductions of SO2, NOx, and mercury. EPA has proposed cap-and-trade regulations to achieve reductions over 28 eastern states and the District of Columbia. The proposal aims to alter existing sections of the Clean Air Act for affected electric generating units and industrial sources opting into the program. EPA believes certain CAA provisions are no longer necessary with Clear Skies. The Administration's Clear Skies proposal aims to simplify regulations under the Clean Air Act for affected electric generating units and industrial sources. EPA believes that certain provisions like New Source Review, regional haze, BART, MACT standards, NOx SIP Call, 126 Rule, and acid rain could be eliminated and combined into a new regulatory process. EPA Administrator Whitman stated that depending on the targets set, these regulations may no longer be necessary.
